bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Vernon Troy Lovett was born in 1945 to Virginia Johnson and Eugene Adkins Lovett, a book keeper, in Williamsburg, Kentucky. Lovett attended Williamsburg High School, class of 1964. He graduated from Cumberland College with a degree in Mathematics in 1969 and continued his studies at Western Kentucky University during the mid-1970's. Lovett taught at Fern Creek High School in Louisville from 1969-2000 as a teacher of mathematics in both the junior and high schools. From 1997-2015, he taught, as an adjunct professor, calculus at Indiana University Southeast-Purdue in New Albany, Indiana. In 1972, Lovett wed Karen Kidd; to their marriage two children were born. In 2014, Lovett married Robbie Roth.

Troy Lovett identifies as a person with borderline schizophrenia and obsessive-compulsive disorder. At age fifteen, November 7, 1960 to December 15, 1960, he began psychiatric treatment at St. Joseph Hospital in Lexington, Kentucky. Later, he was a patient at Highland Hospital in Asheville, North Carolina from March 8, 1961 to June 9, 1962.
Throughout Lovett's academic life and career, he has been an active community member and received various awards and honors including:

Williamsburg High School President, Senior Class President, Junior Class President, Beta Club President, Co-Ed-Y Club President, Youth Center Council President, Methodist Youth Fellowship Basketball team, 5 years Co-Captain, Basketball team Band, 7 years Salutatorian University of Kentucky award for Outstanding Senior Mr. Jacket, Class of 1964
Cumberland College Student Government Association; Methodist Student Movement Band, Campus Choir, Chorale; President of Band; Outstanding Bandsman, 1969 Who's Who in American Colleges and Universities (Twice) Cumberland Alumni Board Alumni Chapter Representative (Kentucky-Indiana) Alumni Association Hall of Honor-one of 100 outstanding graduates honored at Centennial Celebration, 1988
Fern Creek High School Television Resource Teach for Junior High Math, 9 years Judge for Middle School Math Bowl, several years Assistant Basketball Coach under Stan Hardin, 1971-1972 Helped develop and implement innovative Team Teaching of Calculus, 1990-2000 Served on school's first SBDM Council Longtime Master of Ceremonies for Fern Creek Honors Night and Hall of Fame Dinner University of Kentucky, College of Education Teacher Who Made a Difference Award Nominated for Disney Outstanding Teacher Award and Ashland Teacher Award Three times recipient of Jefferson County Brotherhood/Sisterhood Recognition Award Named as Honorary Graduate of Fern Creek High School, 1999 Elected to Fern Creek High School Hall of Fame, 2000
United Methodist Church Member of Christ Church, 48 years Lay Delegate; Pastor-Parish Committee; District Superintendent's Committee Pianist for Vesper and Early Service, 1980-2010
The Thoroughbred Chorus 29-year member with 4 competition medals Served on Board of Directors for over 25 years as President, Membership V.P. Director's Award, 1992, 1996 President's Award, 1998, 2009 "Thoroughbred of the Year", 1999 Chorus Counselor and Unofficial Historian Lifetime Achievement Award, 2016
Sources: Biographical information provided by collection donor, Troy Lovett, in 2022.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Troy Lovett papers (dated1960-2020, undated; 6.29 cubic feet, 7 boxes; 6.32 GB; 17,984 digital files) comprise the correspondence, journals, books, and Highland Hospital subject files gathered and created by Troy Lovett documenting his life and mental health.

The correspondence is mainly to Troy Lovett, from friends and family who wrote to him while he was being hospitalized in 1960 and 1961 for obsessive compulsive disorder. The journals he wrote during and after his hospitalization, up until 1977. They document his life in the hospital, and life at home after hospitalization, including his last years in high school, family life, college, romantic relationships and marriage, and eventually his job as a high school mathematics teacher. The books primarily contain transcripts of all of the journals plus commentary, highlights of the journals, photos, and notes.

The digital records consists of digital copies of Troy Lovett's bound volumes as well as research files, photographs, and scans of correspondence. The digital records were organized by Troy Lovett and remains in their original order.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1960-1974) comprises the mailed letters sent from Troy Lovett's family and friends primarily while he was being hospitalized.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Journals series (1963-1978) comprises the personal journals of Troy Lovett chronicling his hospitalization and beyond.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Books series (2002-2020) is primarily comprised of bound, annotated transcripts of Troy Lovett's journals and letters, along with commentary, photographs, and notes. Additionally, the series includes a volume of his wife's father's WWII letters as well as his own history of Williamsburg, Kentucky, his home town.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject files series (1962, undated) comprises research material about Highland Hospital and its 1938 fire, along with a copy of Lee Edwards High School's newspaper from 1962 and a Cincinnati Baseball Club pamphlet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Digital records series (dated 2005-2020; 6.32 GB; 17,984 digital files) consists of digital copies of Troy Lovett's bound volumes as well as research files, photographs, and scans of correspondence. The books compiled by Troy Lovett consist of transcripts of letters and journals along with annotations and contextual material. The material was organized by Troy Lovett and remains in the original order.
